#id=1
#text=Repairing a flat bike tire can be a little tiring , if you get my drift .
#id=2
#text=Anyway , the last time I had to do this was when I 'd apparently ran over some random , sharp piece of metal that got stuck in my front tire .
#id=3
#text=I had to get some sealant and a little oil for my tire pump .
#id=4
#text=I flipped by bike upside down and used a wrench to take the whole tire off .
#id=5
#text=I have an older bike , so it 's easier to do it this way .
#id=6
#text=I deflated the tire and then I took the outer tire off .
#id=7
#text=I removed the metal bit from the tire and the bladder .
#id=8
#text=I sealed the bladder and had to wait for it to cure .
#id=9
#text=The outer tire got a little bit of repair mix too .
#text=After the various mixes dried , I inflated the bladder a bit and put both the bladder and the tire back on the wheel .
#text=This took a while , since I had to make sure that it was well within the wheel well , so that the tire would stay on .
#text=The last thing I really had to do was fully inflate the bladder and put the tire back on the bike .
#text=It took a little while to do , but it was better than buying an all new tire .
